newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares flat, buyers sidelined.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares flat, buyers sidelined.

text.p: Singapore shares ended almost unchanged on Monday with investors sidelined as the corporate reporting season rolled on.
"Buyers are sidelined because of the reporting season," a dealer at a local broking house said.
Dealers said U.S. inflation and Singapore export data, due Wednesday and Thursday respectively, also had an impact.
"Until the figures get out of the way at the end of the week, we'll have uncertainty hanging over us," he said.
The benchmark Straits Times Industrials Index ended a fraction lower, slipping 0.23 points to close at 2,135.23.
Traded volume was an uninspiring 196.2 million shares which saw losers outstrip gainers by 311 to 82.
The day's most traded counter was debut stock Gul Technologies, which hit an early high of Singapore $0.90 -- a 55 percent premium on its offer price of S$0.58.
Gul ended the day at S$0.79 on volume of 15.7 million units.
Gainers were led by North Borneo Timber, which ended up S$0.80 at a year high of S$9.15. Losers were topped by First Capital warrants, ending down S$0.62 at S$2.36.
